english: beauty that sinks fish and makes birds fall

etymology.description: 沉鱼 (sink fish) + 落雁 (make geese fall) = hyperbolic praise for breathtaking female beauty.
etymology.interpretation: Classical, flowery compliment drawn from legends of beauties whose looks made fish sink and wild geese fall. Used to laud a woman's extraordinary appearance; not typically used for men.
etymology.simplification: Only 鱼 was simplified (魚→鱼) to reduce strokes; other characters unchanged.

parts.english: to sink; to submerge; deep; heavy
fish; fish (as food); aquatic creature; to fish
to fall; to drop; to decline; to set (of sun)
wild goose; swan goose; migratory bird; goose

examples.chinese: 她容貌沉鱼落雁(她容貌沉魚落雁)。
古人以西施、王昭君的美貌为沉鱼落雁(古人以西施、王昭君的美貌為沉魚落雁)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔrén yǐ Xīshī, Wáng Zhāojūn de měimào wéi chényú luòyàn.
examples.english: In antiquity, the beauty of Xi Shi and Wang Zhaojun was described as making fish sink and geese fall.

examples.chinese: 这个词带有夸张和文雅的色彩，多用于称赞女子容貌(這個詞帶有誇張和文雅的色彩，多用於稱讚女子容貌)。
examples.pinyin: Zhège cí dàiyǒu kuāzhāng hé wényǎ de sècǎi, duō yòngyú chēngzàn nǚzǐ róngmào.
examples.english: The term is hyperbolic and literary, mostly used to praise a woman's appearance.
